title: 1 Chronicles Chapter 27 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on 1 Chronicles chapter 27 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: 1 Chronicles Chapter 27 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of 1 Chronicles Chapter 27.

questions.question: Who was the captain over the first course for the first month?
questions.correctAnswer: Jashobeam
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 27:2 states that Jashobeam the son of Zabdiel was over the first course for the first month.

questions.question: How many men were in each monthly course according to 1 Chronicles 27?
questions.explanation: Each course had twenty and four thousand men as stated repeatedly throughout 1 Chronicles 27:1-15.

questions.question: True or False: Benaiah the son of Jehoiada was a chief priest and captain for the third month.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 27:5 confirms Benaiah the son of Jehoiada was the captain of the host for the third month and was a chief priest.

questions.question: Who was the ruler of the Simeonites?
questions.correctAnswer: Shephatiah
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 27:16 states that Shephatiah the son of Maachah was the ruler of the Simeonites.

questions.question: Who took charge of numbering the people but did not finish due to God's wrath?
questions.correctAnswer: Joab
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 27:24 says Joab the son of Zeruiah began to number but did not finish because there fell wrath for it against Israel.

questions.question: What position did Azmaveth the son of Adiel hold?
options: Ruler of the tribe of Dan
questions.correctAnswer: Over the king's treasures
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 27:25 states Azmaveth was over the king's treasures.

questions.question: Who was the captain for the seventh month?
questions.correctAnswer: Helez
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 27:10 says the seventh captain for the seventh month was Helez the Pelonite.

questions.question: True or False: Zadok was the ruler of the Aaronites.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 27:17 identifies Zadok as ruler of the Aaronites.

questions.question: Who was the general of the king's army according to this chapter?
questions.correctAnswer: Joab
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 27:34 states that Joab was the general of the king's army.

questions.question: Who was responsible for the work of the field for tillage of the ground?
questions.correctAnswer: Ezri
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 27:26 states that Ezri the son of Chelub was over the work of the field for tillage.

questions.question: Complete the verse from 1 Chronicles 27:23: 'But David took not the number of them from _______ years old and under.'
questions.correctAnswer: twenty
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 27:23 says David did not take the number of them from twenty years old and under.

questions.question: Who was the king's counsellor mentioned in this chapter?
questions.correctAnswer: Ahithophel
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 27:33 states Ahithophel was the king's counsellor.

questions.question: Who was over the camels according to the chapter?
questions.correctAnswer: Obil the Ishmaelite
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 27:30 identifies Obil the Ishmaelite as over the camels.

questions.question: True or False: Jonathan, David's uncle, was a counsellor and wise man.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 27:32 states Jonathan was a counsellor, wise man, and scribe.

questions.question: Who was captain for the twelfth month?
questions.correctAnswer: Heldai
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 27:15 states Heldai the Netophathite was captain for the twelfth month.

medium.title: 1 Chronicles Chapter 27 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from 1 Chronicles Chapter 27 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is feeling overwhelmed by the responsibilities of leadership and asks how to maintain faith and trust in God. Based on 1 Chronicles 27, what biblical truth would you share about leadership and reliance on God?
options: God appoints leaders over specific roles and seasons, showing His sovereignty in leadership.
Leaders must rely solely on their own strength and wisdom to succeed.
Leadership is only for those who seek power and recognition.
Leaders should avoid accountability to others.
questions.correctAnswer: God appoints leaders over specific roles and seasons, showing His sovereignty in leadership.
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 27 describes leaders appointed over each month and tribe by God’s design (verses 2-15, 16-22), indicating that leadership is under God's sovereign plan, encouraging trust in His guidance.

questions.question: How does 1 Chronicles 27 teach us about the importance of faithful stewardship in daily work and resources?
options: Faithful stewardship involves appointing trustworthy individuals to manage resources diligently.
Resources should be hoarded and not shared with others.
Work is only important if it gains public recognition.
Stewardship is unimportant if one has great wealth.
questions.correctAnswer: Faithful stewardship involves appointing trustworthy individuals to manage resources diligently.
questions.explanation: Verses 25-31 show king David appointed specific leaders over treasures, fields, vineyards, olive trees, and animals, teaching that faithful stewardship means responsibility and integrity in managing resources.

questions.question: When facing spiritual discouragement, how can a believer find encouragement in the organization of Israel's tribes and leaders as shown in 1 Chronicles 27?
options: God’s order and provision for every tribe and leader demonstrates His care and faithfulness.
Spiritual discouragement means God has abandoned His people.
Human organization is more important than trusting God's plan.
Disorganization is a sign of God's displeasure.
questions.correctAnswer: God’s order and provision for every tribe and leader demonstrates His care and faithfulness.
questions.explanation: The detailed listing of tribal leaders in verses 16-22 reflects God’s intentional care and order, encouraging believers that God is faithful and attentive to their lives.

questions.question: A believer struggles with pride in their achievements. Based on 1 Chronicles 27, what biblical truth about humility can you share?
options: Despite mighty warriors and leaders, God’s increase and blessing come by His will, not human strength.
Pride is necessary to lead effectively.
One should boast about their power and position.
questions.correctAnswer: Despite mighty warriors and leaders, God’s increase and blessing come by His will, not human strength.
questions.explanation: Verse 23 states David did not number the people under twenty because God promised to increase Israel like stars, showing blessings come from God’s grace, not human pride.

questions.question: How does 1 Chronicles 27 instruct believers on the importance of obedience and reverence toward God's commands?
options: Disobedience, such as incomplete numbering, leads to God’s wrath and consequences.
God’s commands are optional for leaders.
Obedience only matters in spiritual matters, not in administration.
questions.correctAnswer: Disobedience, such as incomplete numbering, leads to God’s wrath and consequences.
questions.explanation: Verse 24 notes Joab began numbering but did not finish because it caused God’s wrath, teaching obedience protects from judgment.

questions.question: A believer asks how to grow in spiritual maturity and discipline. How does 1 Chronicles 27 model spiritual discipline through service and roles?
options: Spiritual discipline is shown by fulfilling appointed roles faithfully and consistently.
Spiritual growth happens without any effort or responsibility.
Only high leaders need spiritual discipline.
Spiritual discipline is unrelated to serving others.
questions.correctAnswer: Spiritual discipline is shown by fulfilling appointed roles faithfully and consistently.
questions.explanation: The chapter lists many leaders appointed monthly and over tribes (verses 2-22), showing the importance of faithful service and commitment as spiritual discipline.

questions.question: True or False: According to 1 Chronicles 27, David personally numbered all the men of Israel from twenty years old and under.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Verse 23 clearly states David did not number those twenty years old and under because God promised to increase Israel like stars.

questions.question: True or False: According to 1 Chronicles 27, Joab completed the numbering of Israel’s men and recorded it in the chronicles of King David.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Verse 24 states Joab began numbering but did not finish because God's wrath came upon Israel, and the number was not recorded.

questions.question: A believer wants to learn about the value of wise counsel in leadership. Based on 1 Chronicles 27, what biblical truth would you share about seeking wise counsel?
options: Wise counselors like Ahithophel and Hushai played vital roles in advising King David.
Leaders should avoid counsel and make decisions alone.
Counsel is unnecessary if one feels confident.
Only military leaders need wise counsel.
questions.correctAnswer: Wise counselors like Ahithophel and Hushai played vital roles in advising King David.
questions.explanation: Verses 33-34 mention Ahithophel and Hushai as counselors, showing the importance of wise counsel in leadership decisions.

questions.question: How does 1 Chronicles 27 encourage believers to cultivate integrity and honesty in their work and responsibilities?
options: David appointed trustworthy men over different resources and tasks, emphasizing integrity in stewardship.
Leaders can be dishonest if it benefits their position.
Integrity is only necessary in spiritual matters.
questions.correctAnswer: David appointed trustworthy men over different resources and tasks, emphasizing integrity in stewardship.
questions.explanation: Verses 25-31 list leaders over treasures, fields, vineyards, and animals, highlighting the importance of integrity in managing God’s provision.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with contentment amid challenges. Based on 1 Chronicles 27, what biblical truth would you share about contentment and trust in God’s providence?
options: God provides order and leaders for every part of life, encouraging trust and contentment in His plan.
Contentment comes from accumulating wealth and power.
God abandons those who face challenges.
Contentment is irrelevant to spiritual life.
questions.correctAnswer: God provides order and leaders for every part of life, encouraging trust and contentment in His plan.
questions.explanation: The chapter’s detailed structure of leaders and tribes (verses 1-22) reflect God’s providential care, encouraging believers to trust and be content.

questions.question: How does 1 Chronicles 27 illustrate the biblical principle of serving others in the church and community?
options: Leaders and officers were appointed to serve the king and the people diligently in various capacities.
Serving others is optional and not commanded.
Only the king should serve others.
Serving others is only for spiritual leaders.
questions.correctAnswer: Leaders and officers were appointed to serve the king and the people diligently in various capacities.
questions.explanation: Verse 1 and following verses describe officers serving the king monthly, showing service to others as an important biblical principle.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: According to 1 Chronicles 27, over the vineyards was ________, and over the increase of the vineyards for the wine cellars was Zabdi the Shiphmite.
questions.correctAnswer: Shimei the Ramathite
questions.explanation: Verse 27 clearly states Shimei the Ramathite was over the vineyards, showing specific stewardship assignments.

questions.question: How does 1 Chronicles 27 teach about perseverance through trials and challenges in service?
options: Despite challenges, leaders like Joab continued their duties, showing perseverance.
Trials mean God has rejected a person’s service.
Perseverance is unnecessary if duties are difficult.
One should quit service when facing trials.
questions.correctAnswer: Despite challenges, leaders like Joab continued their duties, showing perseverance.
questions.explanation: Verse 24 shows Joab started numbering despite the difficulty, and verses 34 show continued leadership roles, illustrating perseverance.

questions.question: A believer seeks guidance on balancing family life and service. What does 1 Chronicles 27 reveal about family and leadership roles?
options: Leadership roles often passed from father to son, showing the importance of nurturing faith and responsibility in families.
Family has no role in spiritual leadership.
Leaders should neglect family for service.
Only individuals without families can lead.
questions.correctAnswer: Leadership roles often passed from father to son, showing the importance of nurturing faith and responsibility in families.
questions.explanation: Verses 6 and 7 mention leaders and their sons (Benaiah and Ammizabad, Asahel and Zebadiah), highlighting family involvement in leadership.

hard.title: 1 Chronicles Chapter 27 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from 1 Chronicles Chapter 27.

questions.question: Who was the captain over the first course for the first month, and what is significant about his lineage?
options: Jashobeam the son of Zabdiel, of the children of Perez
Dodai an Ahohite, of the tribe of Judah
Benaiah the son of Jehoiada, a chief priest
questions.correctAnswer: Jashobeam the son of Zabdiel, of the children of Perez
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 27:2-3 states Jashobeam was the captain in the first month and he is described as being from the children of Perez, highlighting a notable tribal lineage linked to Judah.

questions.question: Which captain mentioned in 1 Chronicles 27 was also known as 'mighty among the thirty' and what was his role?
options: Benaiah the son of Jehoiada, a chief priest and captain
Joab the son of Zeruiah, general of the army
Helez the Pelonite, captain for the seventh month
Azareel the son of Jeroham, prince of Dan
questions.correctAnswer: Benaiah the son of Jehoiada, a chief priest and captain
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 27:5-6 identifies Benaiah as a mighty man among the thirty and above them, indicating his prominent military and priestly status.

questions.question: Which tribal leaders were responsible for the half tribe of Manasseh according to 1 Chronicles 27?
options: Joel the son of Pedaiah and Iddo the son of Zechariah
Hoshea the son of Azaziah and Jerimoth the son of Azriel
Eliezer the son of Zichri and Shephatiah the son of Maachah
Omri the son of Michael and Azareel the son of Jeroham
questions.correctAnswer: Joel the son of Pedaiah and Iddo the son of Zechariah
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 27:20-21 lists Joel and Iddo as rulers over the two halves of the tribe of Manasseh, highlighting the division of this tribe in Gilead and the west.

questions.question: What is the significance of David not numbering those twenty years old and under as described in this chapter?
options: The LORD promised to increase Israel like the stars of the heavens
David did not have the authority to number them
They were too young to serve in the army
A census was forbidden by Levitical law
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD promised to increase Israel like the stars of the heavens
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 27:23 indicates that David did not number those under twenty because God had promised to increase Israel abundantly, a theological reason rather than a practical one.

questions.question: Who was in charge of the king's treasures and what does this role imply about David's administrative structure?
options: Azmaveth the son of Adiel, indicating a complex royal bureaucracy
Jehonathan the son of Uzziah, showing family involvement in finance
Joab, reflecting military control over finances
Ezri the son of Chelub, emphasizing agricultural revenue
questions.correctAnswer: Azmaveth the son of Adiel, indicating a complex royal bureaucracy
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 27:25 notes Azmaveth's oversight of the treasures, showing specialized roles in David's government for managing wealth.

questions.question: What does the repeated number 'twenty and four thousand' for each monthly course suggest about Israel's military organization?
options: A structured rotation system of equal-sized military units
A symbolic number representing divine completeness
An estimate rather than an actual count
A small elite force for special missions
questions.correctAnswer: A structured rotation system of equal-sized military units
questions.explanation: Throughout 1 Chronicles 27:1-15, each month’s captain commands exactly twenty-four thousand men, indicating an organized, rotating army system.

questions.question: Which two counselors are mentioned as serving King David toward the end of the chapter, and what might their roles signify in the broader biblical narrative?
options: Ahithophel and Hushai, representing conflicting political influences
Joab and Abiathar, signifying military and priestly power
Jehiel and Jonathan, showing family loyalty
Zadok and Hashabiah, emphasizing priestly leadership
questions.correctAnswer: Ahithophel and Hushai, representing conflicting political influences
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 27:33 mentions Ahithophel and Hushai, who later appear in 2 Samuel as rival counselors during Absalom’s rebellion, illustrating political tension.

questions.question: True or False: Joab completed the numbering of Israel’s people without any divine disapproval.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 27:24 states that Joab began the numbering but did not finish because wrath fell on Israel, indicating divine disapproval of the census.

questions.question: What role did Jonathan, David's uncle, have in the king’s administration according to this chapter?
questions.correctAnswer: Counselor, wise man, and scribe
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 27:32 describes Jonathan as a counselor, wise man, and scribe, indicating his advisory and administrative importance.

questions.question: Which captain was responsible for the ninth month, and what tribe was he from according to the text?
options: Abiezer the Anetothite, of the Benjamites
Sibbecai the Hushathite, of the Zarhites
Maharai the Netophathite, of the Zarhites
questions.correctAnswer: Abiezer the Anetothite, of the Benjamites
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 27:12 states that Abiezer, a Benjamite from Anetoth, was captain for the ninth month.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: The ruler of the Reubenites was ________, and the ruler of the Simeonites was ________.
options: Eliezer son of Zichri; Shephatiah son of Maachah
Hoshea son of Azaziah; Jerimoth son of Azriel
Omri son of Michael; Azareel son of Jeroham
Jaasiel son of Abner; Azareel son of Jeroham
questions.correctAnswer: Eliezer son of Zichri; Shephatiah son of Maachah
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 27:16 lists Eliezer son of Zichri as ruler of Reuben and Shephatiah son of Maachah as ruler of Simeon.

questions.question: What is the cultural significance of assigning specific leaders to agricultural resources such as vineyards and olive trees in David’s administration?
options: It reflects the economic importance of these resources in the ancient Near East
It was a symbolic gesture with no practical function
It was meant to segregate tribes by food production
It replaced military leadership with agricultural oversight
questions.correctAnswer: It reflects the economic importance of these resources in the ancient Near East
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 27:27-28 assigns leaders over vineyards and olive trees, highlighting their crucial role in the economy and royal wealth management in that era.

questions.question: Which leader was responsible for the camels in David's kingdom, and why might this be significant in the context of ancient Near Eastern culture?
options: Obil the Ishmaelite, indicating trade and desert mobility
Jehdeiah the Meronothite, emphasizing local transport
Shitrai the Sharonite, reflecting agricultural wealth
Shaphat the son of Adlai, showing pastoral oversight
questions.correctAnswer: Obil the Ishmaelite, indicating trade and desert mobility
questions.explanation: 1 Chronicles 27:30 names Obil the Ishmaelite over camels; camels were vital for trade and desert travel in Near Eastern cultures, suggesting strategic roles.

questions.question: How does the leadership structure described in 1 Chronicles 27 reflect the broader biblical theme of order and governance under God’s sovereignty?
options: It shows a divinely authorized, orderly administration with appointed leaders
It emphasizes human autonomy without divine guidance
It highlights chaos and disorganization in Israel
It focuses only on military strength without civil administration
questions.correctAnswer: It shows a divinely authorized, orderly administration with appointed leaders
questions.explanation: The chapter’s detailed listing of leaders and roles (1 Chronicles 27) reflects biblical themes of God-ordained order and governance in Israel’s society.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT mentioned as a role or responsibility in King David’s administration in this chapter?
questions.correctAnswer: High priest of Israel
questions.explanation: While priestly figures are mentioned, the title 'High priest of Israel' is not explicitly stated in this chapter; Zadok and others are noted but not as High Priest here (1 Chronicles 27:17).

theological.title: 1 Chronicles Chapter 27 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from 1 Chronicles Chapter 27 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to 1 Chronicles 27, how many men were in each monthly military course serving King David?
questions.explanation: Verse 1 states that each course had 24,000 men. This number is repeated consistently for each monthly captain from verses 2 to 15. This reflects God's orderly provision of leadership and strength, consistent with God's command to organize Israel militarily (Exodus 18:21, Numbers 1:3, Joshua 1:14, Luke 3:23).

questions.question: Who was the captain over the first course in the first month as recorded in 1 Chronicles 27?
questions.correctAnswer: Jashobeam
questions.explanation: Verse 2 identifies Jashobeam the son of Zabdiel as the captain of the first course in the first month. Jashobeam is noted as a mighty warrior (2 Samuel 23:8), illustrating God's provision of faithful and capable leaders, consistent with God’s raising up leaders in the Old and New Testament (Exodus 3:10, Acts 13:2, Hebrews 11:32).

questions.question: Which tribe's ruler was Eliezer the son of Zichri according to 1 Chronicles 27?
questions.correctAnswer: Reuben
questions.explanation: Verse 16 states that Eliezer son of Zichri was the ruler of the tribe of Reuben. This shows the tribal organization God established among Israel (Genesis 49:3-4, Numbers 1:5, Deuteronomy 33:6, Hebrews 7:14). The tribal leaders represent God’s covenant people organized for governance and responsibility.

questions.question: What reason does 1 Chronicles 27 give for King David not numbering those under twenty years old?
options: Because the LORD promised to multiply Israel like the stars
Because of a lack of resources
Because they were not eligible for military service
Because David was commanded by Joab
questions.correctAnswer: Because the LORD promised to multiply Israel like the stars
questions.explanation: Verse 23 explains David did not number those under twenty because God had promised to increase Israel like the stars. This underscores God’s sovereign blessing and providence over His people (Genesis 15:5, Hebrews 11:12, Psalm 147:4, Jeremiah 33:22). It reveals God's faithfulness to His covenant promises.

questions.question: Who began the numbering of Israel but did not finish due to divine wrath according to 1 Chronicles 27?
questions.correctAnswer: Joab
questions.explanation: Verse 24 records that Joab began numbering the people but did not finish because wrath fell on Israel. This event highlights God's displeasure with prideful or unauthorized census-taking (2 Samuel 24:1-10, Exodus 30:12, 2 Samuel 24:1, 1 Chronicles 21:1), teaching about human sin and God’s holiness.

questions.question: Who was appointed over the king's treasures as per 1 Chronicles 27?
questions.correctAnswer: Azmaveth
questions.explanation: Verse 25 names Azmaveth son of Adiel as over the king's treasures. This role reflects the responsible stewardship God requires over resources (Matthew 25:14-30, Luke 16:10, Proverbs 3:9, 1 Corinthians 4:2). God's providence includes human management of material blessings.

questions.question: Who was the captain for the third month and also described as 'mighty among the thirty' in 1 Chronicles 27?
questions.correctAnswer: Benaiah son of Jehoiada
questions.explanation: Verses 5-6 identify Benaiah son of Jehoiada as the captain for the third month and as mighty among the thirty, referring to David’s elite warriors (2 Samuel 23:20-23). This exemplifies God raising spiritual and military champions who serve His purposes (Judges 6:12, 1 Samuel 17:34-37, Ephesians 6:10-18).

questions.question: Which of the following was NOT a responsibility assigned to rulers in King David's administration according to 1 Chronicles 27?
options: Over the herds in the valleys
questions.correctAnswer: Over the sea ports
questions.explanation: Verses 27-30 list responsibilities including vineyards, herds in valleys, and camels, but sea ports are not mentioned. This shows the detailed organization of David’s kingdom under God’s sovereign rule (Exodus 18:21-22, 2 Chronicles 19:11, Romans 13:1-7, Psalm 75:6-7).

questions.question: Who was the king's counselor known for his wisdom, as identified in 1 Chronicles 27?
questions.correctAnswer: Jonathan, David's uncle
questions.explanation: Verse 32 states Jonathan, David's uncle, was a counselor, wise man, and scribe. His wisdom reflects God’s provision of godly advisors (Proverbs 11:14, Exodus 18:21, Acts 6:3, Nehemiah 2:7). This illustrates God's guidance through wise counsel in leadership.

questions.question: According to 1 Chronicles 27, who was the king’s companion during David’s reign?
questions.correctAnswer: Hushai the Archite
questions.explanation: Verse 33 identifies Hushai the Archite as the king’s companion, a trusted advisor. His role demonstrates God’s provision of loyal support for the king (Psalm 23:1, Proverbs 27:17, 1 Kings 22:6-8, 2 Samuel 15:32-37).

questions.question: Who was the general of King David’s army as mentioned in 1 Chronicles 27?
questions.correctAnswer: Joab
questions.explanation: Verse 34 states Joab was the general of David’s army. Joab’s leadership under God exemplifies the role of military leadership in accomplishing divine purposes (Joshua 1:14-15, Judges 7:2-7, 2 Timothy 2:3-4, Romans 13:4).

questions.question: What does the detailed listing of tribal rulers and administrators in 1 Chronicles 27 reveal about Israel’s governance under God?
options: God ordains structured leadership for His people
questions.correctAnswer: God ordains structured leadership for His people
questions.explanation: The chapter’s listing of rulers (verses 16-22, 25-31) shows God’s design for orderly governance. This reflects biblical principles of godly leadership (Romans 13:1-7, Exodus 18:21, 1 Timothy 3:1-13, Titus 1:5-9). It underscores God’s providential care and order.

questions.question: How does 1 Chronicles 27 illustrate God’s promise of growth and blessing for His people?
options: By noting God’s promise to increase Israel like the stars
questions.correctAnswer: By noting God’s promise to increase Israel like the stars
questions.explanation: Verse 23 highlights God’s promise to multiply Israel like the stars, reflecting God’s faithfulness to covenant blessings (Genesis 15:5, Hebrews 11:12, Jeremiah 33:22, Psalm 147:4). This promise is foundational for understanding God’s salvation plan.

questions.question: What theological principle can be drawn from the fact that Joab’s census was not completed and incurred wrath, as recorded in 1 Chronicles 27?
options: Human pride and unauthorized actions provoke divine judgment
God does not care about numbers
questions.correctAnswer: Human pride and unauthorized actions provoke divine judgment
questions.explanation: Verse 24 shows God’s wrath fell because Joab’s census was unauthorized or presumptuous, teaching about sin and God’s holiness (2 Samuel 24:1-17, Exodus 30:12, Numbers 1:2, Psalm 51:1-4). This illustrates God’s righteous judgment against disobedience.

questions.question: What does the appointment of officials over diverse economic aspects (vineyards, herds, olive trees, etc.) in 1 Chronicles 27 teach about God's provision?
options: God provides for all areas of life and expects faithful stewardship
The king personally manages all resources
questions.correctAnswer: God provides for all areas of life and expects faithful stewardship
questions.explanation: Verses 26-31 list officials over various resources, showing God’s comprehensive provision and calling for responsible stewardship (Genesis 2:15, Matthew 25:14-30, Luke 12:42-48, 1 Peter 4:10). This reflects God’s sovereignty over creation and human responsibility.
